Transcript:
Blake: Oh, Felicia, I'm so glad you got here so quickly.
Felicia: When you called you sounded really upset.
Blake: Yeah, well, I'm trying not to be. Succeeding admirably. Oh, 
honey, 
just tell me I'm not crazy.
Felicia: I'd prefer it if we didn't use that word.
Blake: Okay, well, then, why am I being so obsessive and jealous? Tell 
me 
why I'm doing this. Tell me there's no good reason for it.
Felicia: And this is all because Ross' assistant...
Blake: Tory granger.
Felicia: ...The young woman who lost her husband, you're upset because

she's throwing herself into her job?
Blake: No. I'm upset because she's throwing herself at Ross. Look, hear 
me 
out. I had planned this romantic lunch with Ross, and just as things were 
starting to heat up, who shows up at the restaurant? Tory-- same time, same 
restaurant.
Felicia: And what, alone?
Blake: No, she was with this guy, Jeff. But listen, listen to this. It 
turns out 
that the casting director calls me in the middle of my lunch and I have to run.
But lo and behold, so does Jeff. Coincidence? I mean, this is their first date.
Not to sound paranoid...
Felicia: But?
Blake: But this knot in the middle of my stomach is telling me that she

engineered this so she could take advantage of my exit and be alone with 
Ross.
Felicia: Doesn't that strike you as just a little...
Blake: Manipulative? Yes.
Felicia: Convoluted?
Blake: No. They spent the rest of the day together. Now, tell me I'm 
crazy 
to think that this little law student is after Ross.
Danny: What do you mean you asked my mother for help? Have you gone 
nuts?
Michelle: Maybe. I'm desperate.
Danny: Honey, it's suicidal. We have got... We are dealing with enough

right now. We're putting our lives on the line for this Mr. Big.
Michelle: Who may or may not be Carmen.
Danny: Look, we don't have any proof it's her.
Michelle: No, we don't, but this way we're going to know for sure.
Danny: Honey...
Michelle: We can handle her. And I don't care what I have to do or who 
I 
have to align myself with. I'm not going to lose you.
Danny: I don't want to lose you either, or Robbie, so why on earth 
would 
you even want to consider doing something like this?
Michelle: Danny, I have a pretty good idea of what Carmen is capable 
of.
But with Mr. Big breathing down our necks, we've got to fight fire with fire.
Danny: What did she say when you asked her?
Michelle: Oh, you know, she wasn't really hot on the idea at first. But 
once 
she realized the danger you're in, she agreed.
Danny: Oh, right. Honey, that's because there's a price attached to it. 
You 
of all people should know that.
Michelle: Well then I'll beat her at her own game. I have so far.
Danny: So then why do you want to push your luck, our luck?
Michelle: Because, Danny, it just makes sense if you think about it. 
Now 
we have to go, actually.
Danny: No. No, honey...
Michelle: We have to go to lunch at towers: You, me, Robbie and Carmen.
Ben: Since you and Marah can't stand each other, I figure...
Catalina: Stop. Stop putting words in my mouth.
Ben: I don't have to. It's obvious. Which makes me wonder, why do you

care if I go after her?
Catalina: I don't. So knock yourself out and good luck. I hope 
everything 
works out for you.
Ben: Hey, thanks. It's awfully nice of you, I mean, considering we just

met, or is it? Because in my experience, when two gorgeous girls are at each 
other's throats, there's usually a man in the middle.

[Captioning sponsored by Procter & Gamble Productions, Inc. And CBS.]
Tony: You know, I almost deleted that essay you sent me with the rest 
of 
my junk mail.
Marah: I wish you had.
Tony: Then why did you send it to me in the first place? Do you think 
you 
can just play games whenever it suits you?
Marah: No.
Tony: But I got to hand it to you, you know? It was some piece of work.
"Making love for the first time should be special. I'm so glad I didn't 
spend the 
night with Tony." You know, why don't you tell me how you really feel, huh?
Marah: Tony, please, will you just at least let me explain?
Tony: Oh, no, you already did. But it would have been bad enough if you

would had just sent it to me, but no. You had to e-mail everybody on campus.
You're so damn proud about the way you feel, huh?
Marah: Please, Tony. I never, ever meant to hurt you.
Tony: What? What? You caused me pain? All right, you didn't. You're not

the only one who's glad we didn't sleep together. I'm even happier than you, 
and relieved, because it would have been just a huge mistake.
Tony: What? What'd you think, huh? You think you're the only one that

felt that way? I'm so glad we didn't sleep together.
Marah: Is that right?
Tony: Yeah, it is, because it would have never lasted. What we had was

nothing special.
Marah: How can you look at me in the eyes and say that?
Tony: Because it's true. You made that perfectly clear when you went

crying running into Sammy's arms, okay?
Marah: Like you ran into Catalina's?
Tony: Hey, what I have with Catalina is none of your business. She's

sweet, she's good to me, and she knows what's private.
Marah: She's really pulled the wool over your eyes.
Tony: No, no Marah. You see, that's the difference between you and her.
She doesn't play games.
Marah: I just hope that she doesn't hurt you, okay?
Tony: Don't worry, she won't. I learn from my mistakes.
Marah: Why are you trying so hard to hurt me?
Tony: I'm not, okay? I'm just telling you how it is, just like you did 
to me, 
except this time I'm saying it to your face.
Marah: Look, Tony, what happened with that essay, it was an accident,

okay? I only wrote that for me. Nobody else was ever supposed to see it. I just

wanted to work some things out.
Tony: Well, bravo, baby, because you had the workout of the century. 
And 
you know what? Since we're being so honest here, let me tell you something.
When I was working for your old man? I felt ashamed of who I was, and I had 
never felt like that in my life. And then I realized there's no reason for me to

apologize for who I am. If people can't accept me because my last name is 
Santos then that's their problem, and Catalina has helped me see that.
Marah: Virtuous, noble Catalina, helping you to see what horrible, 
horrible 
people me and my family really are.
Tony: Look, Catalina likes me for who I am. She's good to me, she's 
proud, okay? Because she sees me as one of the good guys, regardless of what 
you think. So you know what? This is the way I see it. Okay, you're going to 
be holding on to your virginity for a long time because there isn't a guy out

there who's good enough for you. (Sighs)
Danny: Well, I don't know. Honestly, I don't what the hell is crazier: 
You 
asking my mother for help or her agreeing to it.
Michelle: Fine, fine, so it's crazy. But you know what? Your mother is

crazy about you.
Danny: No, she's crazy, period.
Michelle: And she's crazy about her grandson, too. I just played the 
family 
card.
Danny: Right, and that's never worked before, honey. Why do you think 
it 
would work now?
Michelle: Because maybe she is and maybe she isn't pulling the strings, 
be 
we can't afford to take any chances.
Danny: Exactly. So why are you pushing your luck, our luck?
Michelle: Because Danny, if we keep her close, we're going to find out

whether she's really involved or not. And if she isn't, she's got friends in 
high 
places, friends that we could use right now.
Danny: Look, look, I am a firm believer in keeping your enemies close,

but does that mean that we have to go so far as to ask her for help?
Michelle: Danny, in order to defeat your enemy, you have to know what

they want.
Danny: Right, but that doesn't mean we have to have lunch with her and

welcome her into our lives.
Michelle: Just until we're out of the woods. Look, we've risked 
everything 
trying to pull off this heist. If we fail again, we lose everything. Here's 
Tony.
Danny: Hey.
Tony: Hey.
Danny: So, you ready?
Tony: For what?
Danny: A lunch with auntie Carmen.
Tony: Are you nuts?
Carmen: William, I want everything to be perfect. Oh, this, gone.
William: Absolutely.
Maria: Ah, has hell frozen over?
Carmen: Very funny, Maria. Ray, thank you for coming.
Ray: I wouldn't have missed it, Tía Carmen.
Maria: Tell the truth, Carmen. Michelle and Danny aren't coming, are

they?
Carmen: They were the first to be invited and the first to accept.
Maria: Really?
Carmen: Really. As a matter of fact, Michelle made a very endearing 
gesture towards mending fences. And she asked for my help.
Maria: Oh, and you agreed.
Carmen: Yes. Is that so hard to believe?
Ray: Forgiveness is a virtue, abuela. Carmen, I'm pleased you've taken 
a 
step.
Carmen: Thank you.
Maria: Something's not right here.
Carmen: Oh, Maria. We're all capable of change-- even you. And if you

don't believe that, well at least Michelle does.
Blake: So I spend all this time being jealous and suspicious and it's

exhausting.
Felicia: I'll bet. And self-defeating, considering you really don't 
have any 
proof.
Blake: Which is why I'm counting on you to give me a logical 
explanation.
Felicia: Well, for starters, you left Ross to answer Hollywood's call, 
which 
you really didn't have to do. And... Now, hear me out. I want you to listen to

what you said and then draw your own conclusion.
Blake: I'm afraid I'm not going to like it.
Felicia: You not only coerced Tory into wanting a makeover, but you did 
it 
yourself. You transformed her from bookworm into sex kitten, and you 
insisted that Ross hire Tory in the first place.
Blake: So what are you saying, that I did this all to myself?
Felicia: No, but it's not as if Tory's exactly a predatory opportunist.
Blake: Well maybe not at first, but I created a monster.
Felicia: Maybe in your own imagination.
Blake: Thank you.
Felicia: Thank you.
Blake: So what's your diagnosis, huh?
Felicia: Well, could it be that your imagination together with your 
dramatic flair, two qualities which make you a great writer...
Blake: Wait a minute, you're not going to launch into the life 
imitating art 
speech, are you?
Felicia: I'm just paraphrasing what you told me. But see? There you go,

being defensive again.
Blake: Okay, I'll agree with everything except for one thing.
Felicia: What?
Blake: Remember what you said about lying?
Felicia: No, do you?
Blake: Yes. Now when I asked Tory what happened to Jeff, she said he

was called away because of a family emergency. But she was fidgeting and 
she couldn't meet my eyes.
Felicia: I think you're missing the bigger picture here.
Blake: So humor me.
Felicia: Well, maybe Tory was nervous. I mean, averting one's gaze is a

sign of anxiety, or maybe she was just covering for her concern over her date's

welfare.
Blake: Or maybe she planned all of this so she could be alone with 
Ross.
Catalina: You know when rich boys start asking way too many questions,

it's usually because they think they just charm the answers right out of you.
Ben: And who told you I was rich?
Catalina: Nobody had to. It's obvious.
Ben: Oh, and how is that?
Catalina: I've seen you. I've seen you around, diving in that little 
sports car 
of yours, always full of sorority girls.
Ben: So you've been checking me out.
Catalina: No. But it is hard not to notice you the way you drink 
champagne 
while the other guys drink beer.
Ben: What, are you criticizing me for having taste?
Catalina: No, but just because you have money, see that doesn't mean 
that 
I'm just going to start drooling or that you've bought my trust on credit.
Ben: That's too bad, because I was starting to think we work very well

together. As a matter of fact, I was about to suggest a partnership of sorts.
Catalina: Partnership? I don't even know you, and I doubt that we have 
a 
whole lot in common.
Ben: Oh, you might be surprised.
Catalina: I don't think so. See, because I work-- look-- two jobs just 
to fill 
my gas tank, not that I'm complaining. 
Ben: No, of course not.
Catalina: And Marah and I? Marah and I are very, very different. Wait,

don't I remember you saying that you were interested in her?
Ben: Why? Are you giving me an alternative?
Catalina: No. I mean, I don't see what you would need me for. Yeah, I

think you can handle Marah all on your own.
Ben: Hey, your call. But next time you see me driving down the street 
in 
my little sports car, wave your hand if you want a ride. I'll take you anywhere

you want to go.
Catalina: Thanks, but I already got a ride.
Ben: Is that so?
Catalina: Yeah. A reliable one.
Ben: Well, Miss Quesada, it was a pleasure meeting you, and I hope I 
can 
count on you to be discreet.
Catalina: Don't worry. Marah and I, we barely speak, so your little 
secret, 
that's safe with me.
Ben: Okay. Till next time.
Catalina: Tony. When did you get here?
Tony: Not fast enough. Have I told you lately how gorgeous you look,

how much I appreciate you? Mmm. And how delicious you smell?
Catalina: Hey, are you flattering me?
Tony: No. I'm just grateful to have you in my life. Why do I have to go 
to 
this stupid family lunch? I just want to be here with you. Why don't you come

with me, hmm?
Catalina: But I thought it was just for family?
Tony: I don't care. I don't think I can make it without you. I mean, 
it's not 
going to be a thrill a minute, but you think you can stand it? I promise I'll

make it up to you. I'll take you dancing.
Catalina: Oh, yeah?
Tony: Yeah.
Catalina: What kind of dancing did you have in mind?
Tony: We could go salsa dancing, we could go merengue, we could go 
ballroom.
Catalina: No.
Tony: Square dancing?
Catalina: No.
Tony: Come on, tell me you'll come with me, please.
Catalina: Oh, Tony, you had me at salsa. Seriously, I would be honored,

and you don't have to make it up to me. All you have to do is ask.
Tony: I knew it. I knew you were going to say something like that. 
You're 
the most amazing girl. Yeah.
Catalina: All right, shall we go?
Tony: Let's go.
Felicia: So you think that Tory lied about Jeff's family emergency.
Blake: It's possible, isn't it?
Felicia: It's possible, but it's not likely.
Blake: So you really do think I've lost all ability to distinguish fact 
from 
fiction.
Felicia: No! I just think that maybe you're jumping to conclusions-- 
that 
maybe what you're experiencing is a higher than normal level of stress which 
can cause you to be upset and jittery. And come on, feeling threatened, 
assigning blame to a third party who's probably innocent.
Blake: Okay, if she's so innocent, why do I have such an uneasy 
feeling?
Felicia: Have you tried direct, honest communication?
Blake: (Scoffs) no, anything but that.
Felicia: Now, you see? You see how you revert to sarcasm whenever I 
mention honesty?
Blake: Okay, you got me. I'll give it a shot.
Felicia: It'll be worth it, trust me. It's what's kept Clayton and me 
going 
strong all this time, and you'll probably find out that you were wrong all 
along.
Blake: As long as Ross gives me all the right answers.
Ross: Well, hello, ladies.
Blake: Ross.
Ross: Girls-only conversation or may I join you?
Carmen: Well, did I tell you I got my picture in the 
"journal"?
Ray: Well.
Carmen: It wasn't the society pages, but who cares? The most important

thing is that those poor people who are displaced in that horrific earthquake

are being helped. And it makes me feel so good, Ray. You were so right.
When you empty your purse, you fill your heart.
Maria: This may come as an ugly shock, but I hear you can't buy your 
way 
into heaven.
Carmen: How unfortunate for some of us.
Ray: Abuela, Tía, por favor. Please, in the spirit of family and 
forgiveness, 
I propose a cease fire, at least for the duration of the meal, how about it?
Carmen: Yes, yes.
Maria: Okay, okay. It's not like I... Like I have to lift a finger. 
After all, 
Michelle has outwitted you time after time. So I'll just sit back, savor my 
meal, and enjoy the show.
Carmen: Well, I hate to disappoint you, but there won't be any show,

Maria, not unless you count a doting grandmother with her grandson. Ah, and 
there he is. (Laughs) welcome.
Michelle: Thank you.
Carmen: Good boy. I wish I was there with you guys.
Ross: So, was it something I said, do you suppose?
Blake: What?
Ross: Felicia. She couldn't get out of here fast enough. I hope I 
didn't 
interrupt an important conversation.
Blake: No, no, not at all. She just wanted to give us some couple time, 
you 
know. We haven't had a lot of that lately.
Ross: Yes, we've both been busy. 
Blake: Yeah, well, it's good, because I wanted to talk to you about 
something.
Ross: Okay.
Blake: But first of all, I want you to know I... Well, I love you so 
much, 
and I'm proud of you for taking on this pro bono work on top of your already 
very heavy workload. And I think you have a very huge heart and I admire 
you for that.
Ross: But?
Blake: Well, you don't think that we should hide our feelings from each

other, do you?
Ross: Of course not, Blake.
Blake: Even if they're absurd?
Ross: Blake, what's going on?
Blake: Well, you're going to think this is insane, well... See, I'm 
having a 
hard time getting this out.
Ross: Blake, would you just say it?
Blake: Well, the minute I do, I know I'm going to regret it.
Ross: Regret what?
Blake: (Sighs) okay.
Tory: Ross, thank goodness I found you. I've been looking everywhere 
for 
you. Excuse me, are you using this? Thanks.
Ross: What?
Tory: We have a huge problem with the Masterson case.
Ross: Why, what is it?
Tory: Our motion for a continuance was denied.
Ross: Denied? On what grounds?
Tory: Does it matter? What matters is that we have to go to court right

away, which means I have to file that motion for a diversion immediately.
Carmen: Mira que lindo. Esa muchachito. He looks like an angel sleeping

like that. Of course, I haven't seen him as much as I would have liked to, but

whatever. He's not as big as you were, Danny, when you were that age.
Danny: Nope.
Carmen: You know, I would like to propose a toast. To little Roberto. 
My 
favorite thing about you, Michelle.
Michelle: And thank you, Carmen, for inviting us all to lunch.
Carmen: You're welcome.
Michelle: You really didn't have to go to all this trouble.
Carmen: Oh, there will be plenty of time for all that talk after we 
eat, 
Michelle. But for right now, I would like to enjoy the pleasure of your 
company. Thank you for being here. I'm glad all my family's here. It feels so

good. It's been such a long, long time-- even you, Maria. It feels good. And I

would like to make an announcement.
Danny: Boy, this ought to be good.
Carmen: You are looking at the latest purveyor of fine arts.
Ray: Fine arts, as in...
Carmen: Mostly antiquities. With my new import/export business, I am

going to be the hottest art dealer in town and the hottest gallery owner in 
town.
Danny: Selling what? Hot art?
Carmen: (Laughs) no, no, no, Danny. This company is going to be 
completely on the level. Very fine, hard to find, exquisite pieces. I'm very 
proud of it. It's going to be the most enterprising endeavor I've ever 
undertaken in my life. It's going to be fantastic. Antonio, where is he? 
Ray: I called him. Look, there he is right now.
Carmen: Ah.
Tony: Hey.
Carmen: There you are, speaking of the devil, and a handsome one at 
that.
Tony: What, you guys, don't get up. You all look very relaxed.
Maria: Well, Antonio.
Tony: Aunt Carmen, this is Catalina, the one and only lady in my life.
Carmen: Wow. Very nice to meet you.
Catalina: It's nice to meet you as well.
Carmen: Sientate.
Maria: I can see you've won his heart. Congratulations. I just hope you

didn't leave too many blonde bodies in your wake.
Ben: Marah.
Marah: Ben, what are you doing here?
Ben: I thought you might need this.
Marah: Where'd you find it?
Ben: In the classroom. You must have dropped it.
Marah: Thank God you found it. I've just been really scattered lately. 
God, 
better get organized if I don't want to flunk out before midterms.
Ben: Well, I don't think there's much chance of that. But if you want 
to 
take me up on my offer for coffee, we can go over professor Boudreaux's 
lecture.
Marah: Ben, I don't know.
Ben: Listen, as your ta, it is my personal duty to make sure you're 
properly 
caffeinated. I know a great little place right off campus.
Marah: And since when are tas allowed to ask their students out?
Ben: Don't think of it as a date. Think of it as a pair of old friends 
catching 
up.
Marah: You've already asked me out. Two offers, same answer.
Ben: Did I mention that I'm incredibly dense when it comes to 
innuendoes?
Marah: Now, why don't I believe that?
Ben: I don't know. But if you let me steal you off campus for an hour, 
I bet 
you'll thank me. This place makes a mean cup of Joe. Now, come on, what do 
you say?
Marah: So you're a rule breaker? That's good to know.
Ben: Well, I think a good latte's worth bending a rule, don't you?
Marah: Really, really thank you for the offer and for the book, but you

know what? I've got a ton of reading to do and Chem lab...
Ben: Well, did I say we have to go now? We can go whenever you want.
That is, unless you plan to be busy every time I ask.
Marah: That's a possibility. Look, I'm sorry, I've just... I've had a 
couple of 
bad blows lately and don't take this the wrong way but I've kind of sworn off

the male species for a while, understand?
Ben: Oh, Marah, yes. I totally, totally understand.
Marah: You do?
Ben: Look, unlike most guys, I'm... I'm willing to take no for an 
answer.
Marah: Well, that's nice to know.
Ben: But there's something else you should know. Look, I know a lot of

these guys, especially the frat guys, are all after one thing.
Marah: (Chuckles)
Ben: What? You know that. Those losers look at a girl and see nothing

more than a potential score.
Marah: Well, you know what, if you're trying to get me to swear off the

male species forever...
Ben: I'm just trying to remind you that not all guys are like that. 
Some are 
actually mature. And when you've been hurt yourself, you tend to be more 
sympathetic to your partner's needs. Look, I know I don't wear it on my 
sleeve, but I'm one of the good guys. And if you'll give me the chance, I'll 
prove it to you.
Catalina: I didn't push Tony. Actually, he left Marah all on his own.
Maria: Of course he did, once you knocked his socks off. He obviously

likes you very much.
Catalina: Yeah. I like him, too. And I have you to thank. You've been 
like 
a fairy godmother, and very sweet to me, even when I wasn't so sweet to you.
Maria: Well, you always showed me respect, which in my book is even 
better.
Catalina: My life has totally changed. And I couldn't have gone to 
college 
without you. I owe you a great deal of gratitude.
Maria: Oh, no need to go overboard, mi ni. I merely showed you the 
possibilities. You made them a reality. Yeah. You're a smart girl. Who 
knows? With a little luck, maybe someday you'll be part of this happy family.
(Laughs)
Carmen: I have to admit, Antonio, she makes a stunning addition to this

family. To Antonio, the future of our family. Salud.
All: Salud.
Michelle: That's it. That's it. Carmen sees Tony as her way back in.
Danny: Honey, it still doesn't prove she's Mr. Big.
Michelle: Wait, wait, wait. Maybe this makes sense. If she's been 
behind 
the Spaulding heist...
Danny: Honey...
Michelle: ...All the while kissing up to Tony...
Danny: Heads up.
Gus: Hello, hello, everybody, Carmen. You didn't tell me you were 
having 
a family reunion.
Carmen: Well, it must have slipped my mind.
Gus: How am I supposed to guard you if I don't know where and what 
you're doing?
Carmen: Simple: You're not. And as of right now, you're fired.
Tory: So, since our motion for continuance was denied, we'll have to go 
to 
trial immediately.
Ross: Yes. I don't need this. What a nightmare.
Blake: Oh, poor Miss Masterson. And thank goodness, Tory, you're so on

top of things.
Tory: Thank goodness you've been so understanding, Blake. I mean, are

you sure you're not upset about any of this? Lately it seems like I've been 
spending more time with your husband than you he.
Blake: No, I think it's wonderful. I mean, you're taking on such a 
wonderful case. This poor victim accused of murder, no family, no money, no 
one to help her except for Ross and you, of course.
Ross: I have to take care of this. You understand, don't you?
Blake: Of course I do.
Ross: All right. I'll see you guys later, okay?
Tory: Yes, actually, I want to come with you. I want to file that 
motion for 
a diversion.
Ross: Oh, no, no, change of plans. I'm going to pay a little visit to 
this 
judge, and then when I'm through with that, I'll catch up with you. We'll 
exchange information. See you later.
Tory: Okay, great. Well, I better get going, too.
Blake: Actually, you know, Tory, could you wait a minute?
Tory: Sure.
Blake: Great. There's something I want to ask you.
Marah: Well, thank you. I think you almost, almost restored my faith in

men.
Ben: Wow, really? How'd I mange to do that?
Marah: Well, you're not like all the other jerks I've been dealing with

lately.
Ben: I'm glad to hear that. Listen, I understand why you're so 
protective. I 
mean, a girl as gorgeous as you... you got to watch out for yourself. Just be

careful not too punish the nice guys, too. Take it easy, Marah.
Marah: Bye.
Ben: Bye.
Marah: Ben?
Tony: What we had was nothing special.
Marah: How can you look at me in the eyes and say that?
Tony: Because it's true. You made that perfectly clear when you went

crying, running into Sammy's arms, okay?
Marah: Like you ran into Catalina's?
Tony: Hey, what I have with Catalina is none of your business.
Frat guy: Well, dude, you bag her yet?
Ben: My friend, Marah Lewis is a vulnerable, sensitive young woman. I

figure a couple of weeks, tops. (Snickering) this is a bet I intend to win.
Tory: So, what'd you want to ask me, Blake?
Blake: Don't look so scared. I just want to see how things were going.
With Jeff. Has he called you?
Tory: No, not since our date tanked.
Blake: Oh, that's too bad.
Tory: That's okay. I wasn't really holding my breath. You know, we 
didn't 
exactly click.
Blake: You didn't? Oh, that is too bad. I thought he was kind of cute.
Tory: Yeah, sure he was cute, but he's just so...
Blake: So what?
Tory: Young.
Blake: Young? He has to be at least a couple of years older than you.
Tory: Yeah, I know, but I just don't relate.
Blake: Oh. Well, that's silly because you have the same classes, the 
same 
aspirations. Now, one way to get through loss is by distraction. You do need 
to move on at some point, Tory. I think even Stewart would agree.
Tory: Yeah, I know. I just... I just feel so much older now, and I'm 
not 
trying to be tragic.
Blake: I didn't say that you were.
Tory: I just feel like I don't have much patience for guys like Jeff. I 
mean, 
if I were to be in another relationship, I think it would have to be with 
someone a lot older, I mean, someone who's had more worldly experience. I 
mean, you understand. Is this really what you wanted to talk about?
Blake: No. No, it's not. And I'm sorry about Jeff, I am, but selfishly, 
I'm 
relieved. Because I am going out of town for a couple of days.
Tory: Oh, you're going back to Hollywood?
Blake: No, no. My... my old college roommate is having surgery.
Tory: Oh, my goodness, is she all right?
Blake: Oh, she's fine. Nothing serious, she just needs a couple of days 
to 
recover and she's all alone.
Tory: Oh, okay, well, whatever you need me to do.
Blake: Yeah, well, I'm farming out the kids. The boys are going to have 
a 
sleep over and Clarissa will be with Holly, so I figured you and Ross will be

burning the midnight oil.
Tory: Probably.
Blake: Yeah. Well, when the family's gone, he tends not to take care of

himself. So I was kind of hoping that you would look after him. You know, 
make sure he doesn't eat straight out of the tin, things like that. I'd 
appreciate 
it.
Gus: What exactly are you trying to pull, mmm?
Carmen: What do you think?
Gus: We had a deal, Carmen: You give me Danny and you get to walk 
around free like this. Are you enjoying yourself, because you are skating on 
thin ice.
Carmen: I gave you not only one but two chances at trying to arrest 
Danny 
and you failed miserably at both. Well, I won't. Watch and learn, Aitoro. Bye-
bye.
Michelle: Are you thinking what I'm thinking?
Danny: Mm-hmm. She fired Aitoro to score points with us?
Michelle: Smartest move she's made in a long time.
Danny: I just don't know if I can put up with this long enough to find 
out 
what we need.
Michelle: We will. He will.
Carmen: Well. Well, excuse me for that rude interruption, but with 
Machado in jail and my family with me, who needs that loser bodyguard?
Another toast. To the family. To the enduring prosperity of the Santoses. May

we one day command as much respect as all the powerful families in 
Springfield. Salud.
Danny: To our future.
All: Salud.
